page.lettertext:
fol.116r
Belgia 1592 25 March To M
r
Bodly
S
r
. Yo
r
last letter I have recevid is of the xv
th
of
[this mo-]
neth, by w
ch
emongest other thinges, I find that yowe
[are desi-]
rous to have hir
Ma
ties
pleisure signified unto yowe in two things.
[The]
first is, howe yowe shall awnsweare the
Empero
rs
Ambass
[ado
rs
in]
the matter [semed] to be offred by him to induce the Empero
r
to se
[nd an]
Ambassade to hir Ma
tie
, for the Treatie of Peace, and the
[.]
hir Ma
tie
being acquainted w
th
yo
r
owne manner of proceedi
[ng]
w
th
that Ambassado
r
alloweth vearie well therof, wisshing
[.]
to continue the same kinde of language as of yo
r
self, not
provoking him thereto in hir Ma
ties
name, but to declare yo
r
opinion, that hir Ma
tie
will never mislike of anie motion to
[.]
soe she maie finde it w
th
good sinceritie, and from soe gre
[at a]
Prince as the Empero
r
is, yowe cannot thinke but yt shall
[be]
well accepted: all w
ch
speeches must be used as of yo
r
self
[.]
as directed from hir Ma
tie
./.
The second matter is for Inducc
o
n of the
States
theare to be
[.]
to send this Sommer time, sum of their forces to aide the
[French]
Kinge,
wheareof she alloweth greatlie, w
th
the Caution
[.]
by yo
r
self, that yt be not stirred in before the full accord
[of]
Contribuc
o
n of the provinces intended for the warre this next
[year]
least the evill willers to the matter of
France,
showld
[dissuade the]
Contribuc
o
n for the warre of France, seeing the same hath been
propounded to make warre theare at home./.
At this time yowe shall receive letters from my
LLs
of the C
ouncil
uppon occasion of letters sent from thence of late unto hir M
a
tie
to treate w
th
the
Counsell
theare that
S
r
Edward Norris
,
[who is]
called to appeare before them to awnsweare to such thing
[as they]
have to Charge him w
th
all, whearein I doe frendlie requ
[est yowe]
to deale in all good sort as S
r
Edward Norris maie thinke him
beholdinge unto yowe, wheareof I doe not write for anie
[.]
I have my self, but both yowe have and will showe him
[all the]
favo
r
that yowe maie, against the Burghers of thos Couns
[ell]
but because I doe knowe yt that he himself hath other w
[ise]
conceived dowbtfullie of yo
r
dealinge for him: And in soe d
[ oing ]
I shall thinke my self beholding to yowe, for that
[.]
Gentleman both for himself and parent
.
From the
[Cort]
xxv
th
of Marche. 1592.
Yo
r
verie Lovi
nge
fren[de] William Burghley
